bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ernest Lundeen, August 16, 1940

div1.p: Hench states that Lambert has no legitimate basis for a claim to be included on the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ernest Lundeen, August 16, 1940
div1.opener:
leave on desk.
Yellow Fever.
August 16, 1940
Senator Ernest Lundeen
United States Senate
Washington, D. C.
My dear Senator Lundeen:
div1.p:
I am writing to you as a member of the Senate Military Affairs
Committee, which will shortly have brought before it the proposal to add the
name of Gustav E. Lambert, formerly of the Army Hospital Corps, to the Yellow
Fever Roll of Honor. As you of course know, the Roll of Honor carries each
year the names of those who were particularly concerned with the conquest of
yellow fever, the United States Army Commission, headed by Walter Reed. As
you also know, the particular services of each man were described and gathered
together in United States Senate Document, Volume 61, No. 822. I understand
that from time to time since the Roll of Honor was created, false claimants
have tried to have their names added to this list.

I don't know just who Lambert is, as I never heard of him before,
but I can assure you, from my knowledge of the work of Walter Reed and his
efforts, that so far as I know, he has not the slightest claim to have his name
connected in any way with this Yellow Fever Roll of Honor.

Three years ago, the president of Washington and Jefferson College
asked me to be present on the occasion, in October, 1940, of the dedication of
the Lazear Memorial Building. Jesse Lazear was, with Walter Reed, one of the
four members of the Army Yellow Fever Board, which discovered the cause of this
disease. The president asked me to prepare an address on the history and the
conquest of yellow fever. I have spent much time in the last three years in-
vestigating in minute detail the work of the Board, as I have become fascinated
by this story. It has involved visits to the homes of several of the survivors
of these experiments, including that of Mr. John Kissinger in Huntington, Indiana,
and Mr. John J. Moran in Havana. A couple of months ago, I spent several days
in Havana, visiting the former sites of the experiments, and several survivors of
the work. I have read everything I could find on these experiments, official and
unofficial, and can, I think, properly say that I am familiar with the names of
everyone directly connected therewith, and even the names of many indirectly
associated. Not once has the name of Gustav E. Lambert over appeared.

May I submit this protest to you, that continued encroachment on this
Roll of Honor should not be countenanced. I should be interested to know on what
basis he claims the right of being admitted to the Roll of Honor and I should
certainly like to hear the outcome of the matter.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
